awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Allison Miller is "Satellites and knot concordance." The host institution for the fellowship is Rice University, and the sponsoring scientist is Shelly Harvey.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
As an NSF Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellow at Rice University (2019-2021) and Swarthmore College (2021-2022),  I made progress on a variety of projects in knot concordance,  the study of 4-dimensional properties of knots and surfaces.  More specifically, my work has focused on understanding the extent to which algebraic invariants constrain and even determine topological structure in dimension four.  Some of my results are as follows.
In joint work with Mark Powell (Durham University),  we gave new quantitative lower bounds on how many ``1-handle moves'' it takes to relate two surfaces embedded in the four ball.   
In joint work with Peter Feller (ETH Zurich),  Matthias Nagel (ETH Zurich),  Patrick Orson (MPIM Bonn),  Mark Powell (Durham University) and Arunima Ray (MPIM Bonn),  we proved a complete characterization of when certain simple 4-manifolds admit simple generators for their second homology groups..
I also used Casson-Gordon invariants to give the first example of knots with large genera satisfying a range of properties: negative amphichirality,  rational sliceness, vanishing positive and negative clasp number. 

While an NSF postdoc, I was able to use my funding to travel both to visit collaborators and to attend conferences in my research area.  In particular, the paper with Feller-Nagel-Orson-Powell-Ray would not have occurred without the opportunity to collaborate at and after a conference in Bonn,  Germany that I was able to attend due to this support.  Additionally, the release from teaching duties during much of my time at Rice enabled me to contribute to broader community in other ways: I designed and ran MathExp,  an outreach mathematical exploration program for local middle school students,  as well as organizing reading courses and learning seminars in the department.  I was also able to pilot a mini-seminar on ethics in mathematics that I plan to build upon in my future teaching.  Having transferred my postdoc to Swarthmore, I have benefited from the proximity to other Philadelphia area schools, particularly Bryn Mawr, Haverford, and Temple,  where I have participated and spoke in local seminars.


Selected publications:

    Stabilization distance between surfaces, joint with Mark Powell, L’Enseignement Mathématique 65 no. 3/4 (2019), pp. 397-440. 
    
        Embedding spheres in knot traces, joint with Peter Feller, Matthias Nagel, Patrick Orson, Mark Powell, and Arunima Ray, Compositio Mathematica 157 no. 10 (2021) pp. 2242-2279.  
        
            Branched covers bounding rational homology balls, joint with Paolo Aceto, Jeffrey Meier, Maggie Miller, JungHwan Park, and András Stipsicz, Algebraic & Geometric Topology 21  no. 7 (2021), pp 3569–3599. 
    
        Amphichiral knots with large 4-genus,  Bulletin of the London Mathematical Society 54 (2022), pp. 624-634.



Last Modified: 06/16/2022
Modified by: Allison N Miller
